pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 117, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 194, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 505, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 353, 115, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>+</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 599, 369]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 369, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 416, 275, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 462, 327, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 493, 327, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 507, 680, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 549, 219, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 566, 568, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 702, 89]]<|/det|> A student uses a metre ruler to measure the length of a sheet of paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 581, 119]]<|/det|> Which measurement is shown to the nearest millimetre? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 133, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 129, 232, 147]]<|/det|> 0.2932 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 129, 300, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 129, 390, 147]]<|/det|> 0.293 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 129, 467, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 129, 544, 147]]<|/det|> 0.29 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 129, 636, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 129, 702, 147]]<|/det|> 0.3 m <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 175, 97, 193]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 175, 640, 193]]<|/det|> A rocket travels with an average speed of \(6\mathrm{km / s}\) for 2 minutes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 205, 484, 223]]<|/det|> What is the distance travelled by the rocket? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 234, 133, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 234, 203, 252]]<|/det|> 12 km <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 234, 298, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 234, 371, 252]]<|/det|> 50 km <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 234, 467, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 234, 548, 252]]<|/det|> 720 km <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 234, 635, 252]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 234, 740, 252]]<|/det|> 12 000 km <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 280, 96, 298]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 280, 922, 312]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the vertical forces acting on a ball as it falls vertically through the air. The ball does not reach terminal velocity. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 322, 561, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 505, 920, 539]]<|/det|> Which row describes what happens to the resultant force on the ball and what happens to the acceleration of the ball as it falls through the air? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 494, 680]]<|/det|>
resultant forceacceleration
Adecreasesdecreases
Bdecreasesincreases
Cincreasesdecreases
Dincreasesincreases

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A coconut falls from a palm tree. At X, it has just started falling. Y is the point just before it hits the ground.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 112, 608, 384]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 393, 489, 410]]<|/det|>
What is the acceleration of the coconut at X?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 422, 378, 440]]<|/det|>
(Air resistance can be ignored.)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 451, 141, 468]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 451, 191, 468]]<|/det|>
zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 477, 131, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 477, 304, 495]]<|/det|>
less than that at Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 131, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 504, 331, 521]]<|/det|>
the same as that at Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 131, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 530, 312, 548]]<|/det|>
more than that at Y

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 574, 96, 592]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 574, 616, 592]]<|/det|>
A car is driven round a bend in the road at a constant speed.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 598, 670, 757]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 768, 823, 787]]<|/det|>
What is the direction of the resultant force on the car when it is going round the bend?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 797, 131, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 797, 655, 816]]<|/det|>
parallel to the motion and in the same direction as the motion

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 823, 131, 841]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 823, 677, 841]]<|/det|>
parallel to the motion and in the opposite direction to the motion

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 850, 131, 868]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 850, 670, 868]]<|/det|>
perpendicular to the motion and towards the inside of the bend

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 877, 133, 895]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 877, 680, 895]]<|/det|>
perpendicular to the motion and towards the outside of the bend

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a drawbridge that is attached to a wall by a hinge at one end and a cable at the other.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 114, 698, 293]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 305, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
The weight of the drawbridge and the tension in the cable are represented by the labelled arrows in the diagram. There is a third force at the hinge, which is not shown. The drawbridge is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 365, 662, 384]]<|/det|>
Which arrow shows a possible direction for the force at the hinge?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 392, 791, 460]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 485, 96, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 601, 504]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives the momentum change of an object?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 516, 134, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 515, 384, 540]]<|/det|>
momentum change = \(\frac{\text{force}}{\text{area}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 549, 134, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 467, 567]]<|/det|>
momentum change = force \(\times\) distance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 580, 134, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 579, 470, 604]]<|/det|>
momentum change = force \(\times\) distance

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 616, 134, 633]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 616, 432, 633]]<|/det|>
momentum change = force \(\times\) time

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 660, 129, 678]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 660, 777, 678]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the use of nuclear fuel as an energy resource is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 134, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 688, 432, 707]]<|/det|>
It obtains its energy from the Sun.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 715, 134, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 715, 415, 733]]<|/det|>
It has no environmental impact.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 742, 134, 761]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 742, 526, 759]]<|/det|>
Nuclear power stations do **not** need turbines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 768, 134, 785]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 768, 499, 785]]<|/det|>
The energy is released by nuclear fission.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows an object of mass \(m\) being projected with speed \(v\) from a point P to a point Q on top of a cliff height \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 115, 702, 135]]<|/det|>
The object does work \(W\) against air resistance as it travels from P to Q.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 141, 700, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 299, 648, 318]]<|/det|>
What is the kinetic energy of the object when it reaches point Q?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 330, 134, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 329, 301, 349]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} m\dot{v}^{2} + mgh + W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 133, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 361, 301, 381]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} m\dot{v}^{2} + mgh - W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 133, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 394, 301, 413]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} m\dot{v}^{2} - mgh + W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 427, 133, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 427, 301, 445]]<|/det|>
\(\frac{1}{2} m\dot{v}^{2} - mgh - W\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 475, 104, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 591, 494]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a Sankey diagram for an electric drill.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 502, 744, 745]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 749, 740, 767]]<|/det|>
scale: distance between two lines = 40 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 780, 576, 799]]<|/det|>
What is the total wasted energy shown by the diagram?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 809, 134, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 809, 198, 827]]<|/det|>
120 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 808, 311, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 808, 366, 827]]<|/det|>
200 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 808, 480, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 808, 534, 827]]<|/det|>
360 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 808, 641, 827]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 808, 700, 827]]<|/det|>
560 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 670, 89]]<|/det|>
An elephant of weight \(45 000 \text{N}\) stands with all four feet on the floor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 845, 120]]<|/det|>
The average pressure on the floor due to the elephant foot in contact with it is \(34 000 \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 494, 149]]<|/det|>
What is the area of each foot of the elephant?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 159, 134, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 159, 218, 178]]<|/det|>
0.19 m²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 160, 298, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 160, 386, 178]]<|/det|>
0.33 m²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 160, 467, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 160, 551, 178]]<|/det|>
0.76 m²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 160, 636, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 160, 710, 178]]<|/det|>
1.3 m²

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 205, 106, 224]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 205, 667, 224]]<|/det|>
Some air is trapped inside a metal container with a tightly fitting lid.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 233, 650, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 440, 920, 475]]<|/det|>
The container is heated strongly behind a safety screen. The lid is blown off by the increased pressure of the air inside the container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 486, 685, 505]]<|/det|>
What causes the increase in pressure of the air inside the container?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 134, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 515, 574, 534]]<|/det|>
Each air particle expands and takes up more room.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 542, 134, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 542, 453, 560]]<|/det|>
The air particles move more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 570, 131, 587]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 568, 604, 587]]<|/det|>
The number of particles inside the container increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 596, 133, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 594, 507, 613]]<|/det|>
The volume occupied by the air decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 640, 104, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 640, 895, 658]]<|/det|>
A very hot mug of coffee is near a large unheated swimming pool holding \(2.0 \times 10^{6} \text{kg}\) of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 669, 348, 687]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 131, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 697, 920, 732]]<|/det|>
If the mug of coffee is tipped in the pool, the coffee will lose much more internal energy than the water in the pool gains.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 131, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 715, 757]]<|/det|>
The internal energy of a substance depends only on its temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 766, 131, 784]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 766, 920, 799]]<|/det|>
The internal energy of the water in the pool is lower than the internal energy of the mug of coffee.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 807, 133, 825]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 806, 821, 825]]<|/det|>
When the temperature of the mug of coffee falls, its internal energy will decrease.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|> A student measures the mass of water in an open container over two hours. The container is kept in a warm room. The results are in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[332, 114, 665, 270]]<|/det|>
time/hoursmass of water/g
0.033.9
0.530.6
1.027.6
1.524.9
2.022.5
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 281, 460, 300]]<|/det|> Why does the mass of the water change? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 134, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 310, 339, 327]]<|/det|> The water evaporates. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 134, 354]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 336, 308, 354]]<|/det|> The water freezes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 134, 380]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 362, 336, 380]]<|/det|> The water condenses. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 389, 133, 406]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 389, 285, 406]]<|/det|> The water boils. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 433, 104, 451]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 433, 920, 467]]<|/det|> A \(1\mathrm{kg}\) block of aluminium requires more thermal energy to raise its temperature by \(1^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) than a \(1\mathrm{kg}\) block of copper requires. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 478, 220, 496]]<|/det|> Why is this? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 507, 131, 524]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 507, 675, 526]]<|/det|> Aluminium is a better conductor of thermal energy than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 131, 552]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 677, 552]]<|/det|> Aluminium is a poorer conductor of thermal energy than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 561, 131, 579]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 561, 635, 579]]<|/det|> Aluminium has a higher specific heat capacity than copper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 587, 131, 604]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 587, 630, 604]]<|/det|> Aluminium has a lower specific heat capacity than copper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|> A block of ice is at a temperature of \(- 100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). Energy is supplied at a constant rate. The graph shows how its temperature changes. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[212, 114, 779, 285]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 920, 333]]<|/det|> At which points have the ice completely changed state to water and all the water completely changed state to steam? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 343, 520, 490]]<|/det|>
completely changed to watercompletely changed to steam
A13
B14
C23
D24
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 515, 104, 534]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 515, 492, 534]]<|/det|> Water waves are reflected at a plane surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 546, 594, 565]]<|/det|> Which property of the waves is changed by the reflection? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 134, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 349, 593]]<|/det|> direction of propagation <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 134, 619]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 602, 238, 619]]<|/det|> frequency <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 134, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 628, 207, 645]]<|/det|> speed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 654, 134, 672]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 654, 250, 672]]<|/det|> wavelength

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 430, 89]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles are directed at a metal foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 698, 120]]<|/det|>
Most of the particles pass through the foil with little change in direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 730, 150]]<|/det|>
A small proportion of the particles are scattered back through large angles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 163, 655, 180]]<|/det|>
What does this evidence suggest about the structure of an atom?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 191, 134, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 191, 920, 223]]<|/det|>
It consists of a charged centre much smaller than the size of the atom and with little of the mass of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 233, 134, 250]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 233, 920, 265]]<|/det|>
It consists of a negative charge the size of the atom containing small positive charges scattered through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 273, 131, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
It consists of a charged centre much smaller than the size of the atom but with most of the mass of the atom.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 313, 133, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 313, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
It consists of a positive charge the size of the atom containing small negative charges scattered through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 373, 106, 390]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 373, 848, 390]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly compares the properties of alpha-particles and beta-particles?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 402, 133, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 402, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
Alpha-particles are less penetrating than beta-particles because alpha-particles are less ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 444, 133, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 444, 920, 476]]<|/det|>
Alpha-particles are less penetrating than beta-particles because alpha-particles are more ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 133, 502]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 484, 920, 516]]<|/det|>
Alpha-particles are more penetrating than beta-particles because alpha-particles are less ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 526, 133, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 526, 920, 558]]<|/det|>
Alpha-particles are more penetrating than beta-particles because alpha-particles are more ionising.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 585, 106, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 585, 504, 603]]<|/det|>
Which statement about alpha decay is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 613, 133, 631]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 390, 631]]<|/det|>
The nucleus loses electrons.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 133, 658]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 640, 571, 657]]<|/det|>
The nucleus changes to that of a different element.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 667, 133, 684]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 667, 571, 684]]<|/det|>
The nucleus does not decay until after one half-life.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 692, 133, 710]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 692, 534, 710]]<|/det|>
After two half-lives, alpha decay always stops.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 740, 106, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 739, 895, 757]]<|/det|>
An explosion in a nuclear reactor spreads the isotope caesium-137, \(^{137}_{55}\mathrm{Cs}\), across a large area.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 772, 897, 790]]<|/det|>
After 90.0 years have passed, the quantity of caesium-137 present is \(12.5\%\) of its original level.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 803, 420, 820]]<|/det|>
What is the half-life of caesium-137?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 831, 133, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 831, 240, 848]]<|/det|>
11.3 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 831, 303, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[325, 831, 401, 848]]<|/det|>
22.5 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 831, 470, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 831, 576, 848]]<|/det|>
30.0 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 831, 636, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 831, 744, 848]]<|/det|>
45.0 years

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 667, 90]]<|/det|>
Which type of object rotates around the Sun with an elliptical orbit?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 100, 208, 117]]<|/det|>
planet

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 134, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 125, 213, 144]]<|/det|>
galaxy

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 152, 228, 170]]<|/det|>
red giant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 178, 201, 196]]<|/det|>
moon

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 470, 241]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the Sun is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 250, 133, 268]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 250, 784, 268]]<|/det|>
The nuclear reactions in the Sun create mainly radio waves and microwaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 276, 133, 294]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 276, 843, 294]]<|/det|>
The Sun is powered by fission reactions in which hydrogen is converted into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 133, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 303, 819, 320]]<|/det|>
The Sun is powered by fission reactions in which lithium is converted into helium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 329, 133, 348]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 329, 834, 346]]<|/det|>
The Sun is powered by fusion reactions and electromagnetic radiation is produced.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 373, 102, 392]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 373, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
To determine the value of the Hubble constant, an astronomer measures the distance of a galaxy from the Earth as \(2.5 \times 10^{21} \text{km}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 420, 858, 439]]<|/det|>
She also measures the speed of recession of the galaxy from the Earth as \(5.2 \times 10^{3} \text{km/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 450, 603, 469]]<|/det|>
From these data, what is the value of the Hubble constant?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 480, 133, 497]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 480, 268, 497]]<|/det|>
\(7.7 \times 10^{- 26} \text{s}^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 133, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 508, 268, 526]]<|/det|>
\(2.1 \times 10^{- 18} \text{s}^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 133, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 536, 260, 554]]<|/det|>
\(4.8 \times 10^{17} \text{s}^{- 1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 133, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 562, 260, 581]]<|/det|>
\(1.3 \times 10^{25} \text{s}^{- 1}\)
